titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Henry O'Reilly Papers
1819-1880 (Bulk 1844-1860)
MS 464
titlestmt.author: Rohinie J. Munzel

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from oreilly02MH.xml

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 15:49:24 -0400.

did.physloc: Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
did.abstract: The Papers of Henry O'Reilly, dating from 1832 to 1873, consist of 28 linear feet of material. The bulk of these papers date from 1844 to 1860. The O'Reilly Papers contain the following types of material: business and personal correspondence (letters, telegraph messages), minutes, proceedings, organizational documents (charters, by-laws, articles of incorporation and association), financial documents (bills, receipts, invoices, expenditure sheets, accounts, bank drafts, promissory notes, inventories, stock certificates), legal documents (contracts, conveyances, indentures, deeds, leases, affidavits, depositions, insurance policies, mortgages, memoranda), notes, reports, scrapbooks, and printed material (pamphlets, proofs, circulars, flyers, clippings).
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.

Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the Henry O'Reilly Papers, MS 464, New-York Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note

eventgrp.event: Born in Carrickmacross, Province of Ulster, Ireland
Came to New York, New York, Learned printer's trade
Assistant Editor of the New York Patriot
Editor of the Rochester Daily Advertiser
Appointed Deputy Collector and Inspector for the District of Genesee, New York
Began advocating rebuilding and enlargement of the Erie Canal
Appointed Post Master of Rochester, Published Sketches of Rochester
President of Rochester Athenaeum and Young Men's Association
Recording Secretary, New York State Agricultural Society
Entered into contract with Samuel F.B. Morse and Amos Kendall for erecting telegraph lines in the United States
Established Irish and American Steamship Company
Organized Demoine Navigation and Railroad Company

bioghist.p: Henry O'Reilly was born in Carrickmacross, Province of Ulster, Ireland on Feb. 6, 1806 to a merchant and the daughter of a physician. In 1816, the family emigrated to New York. After working as an apprentice in the printing trade including several years as an assistant editor of the New York Patriot, in 1826 O'Reilly was appointed editor of the Rochester, NY, Daily Advertiser. Within a year, O'Reilly gained notice in the anti-Masonic uproar that followed the kidnapping and murder of William Morgan. In 1832, he was appointed Deputy Collector and Inspector for the District of Genesee, NY. He published numerous circulars and pamphlets on current events and issues, and in 1838 Sketches of Rochester, with Incidental Notices of Western New York. In that same year, O'Reilly was appointed Post Master of Rochester. From the 1830s through the 1850s, he was heavily involved in civic and political organizations, serving as the President of the Rochester Athenaeum and Young Men's Association, Recording Secretary of the New York State Agricultural Society, and Chairman of the Clinton League.

O'Reilly's commercial activities were similarly energetic and varied. In 1833, he threw his support behind improvements to the Erie Canal. In 1845, he contracted with Samuel F.B. Morse and Amos Kendall in the planned construction of telegraph wires from eastern Pennsylvania to the Great Lakes. Legal difficulties ended his involvement with the enterprise, despite his erection of over 8,000 miles of wire. In 1851, O'Reilly established the Irish and American Steamship Company; in 1854, he organized the Demoine Navigation and Railroad Company.

O'Reilly was married to Marcia Brooks, daughter of General Micah Brooks; they had one son, Henry Brooks O'Reilly, who was killed in the Battle of Williamsburg, 1862. Late in his life, O'Reilly changed the spelling of his surname to O'Rielly; additional papers of O'Reilly may be found under this variant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Henry O'Reilly, dating from 1819-1880, consist of 28 linear feet of material. The bulk of the papers date from 1844 to 1860 and include the following forms: business and personal correspondence, minutes, proceedings, organizational records, financial records, legal records, notes, reports, scrapbooks and printed matter.

The O'Reilly Papers document the diverse activities of Henry O'Reilly in Rochester, NY; the Genesee District; and New York State. Specific topics addressed include: the establishment of telegraph lines; the development, improvement and operations of the transportation industry, particularly canals, steamships and railroads; local and state politics; civic and cultural organizations; journalism; typography; American Indians; agriculture; government reform; the postal service; public schools; land purchases in Western Virginia; and the military career of O'Reilly's son.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence within series are usually arranged alphabetically for letters received, chronologically for letters sent. Unidentified letters received and correspondence between others arranged chronologically.

The documents have been arranged in twenty-four series, the last of which includes materials inventoried and added to the finding aid in April 2022. Many of the series have been arranged in subseries.
Series I: General Correspondence, 1837-1872
Series II: Telegraph Enterprise, 1844-1861
Series III: Demoine Navigation and Railroad Company, 1849-1858
Series IV: Erie Canal Enlargement, 1836-1841
Series V: Clinton League, 1859
Series VI: New York State Agricultural Society, 1841-1856
Series VII: Politics, 1836-1857
Series VII: Post Office, Rochester, 1838-1844
Series IX: Common Schools, Rochester, 1838-1840
Series X: Rochester Athenaeum and Young Men's Association, 1838-1840
Series XI: Western Virgina Lands, 1838-1856
Series XII: Albany Irish Repeal Association, 1843
Series XIII: American Indians, 1838-1860
Series XIV: Deputy Collector and Inspector of District of Genesee, 1832-1842
Series XV: Irish and American Steamship Company, 1851
Series XVI: New York Typographical Society, 1849
Series XVII: Rochester Daily Advertiser, Undated
Series XVIII: Sketches of Rochester, Undated
Series XIX: Legal Documents, 1832, 1840-1851, 1857
Series XX: Financial Documents, 1834-1859
Series XXI: Notes and Fragments, 1840-1859
Series XXII: Personal and Family Papers, 1832-1862
Series XXIII: Printed Material, 1830-1869
Series XXIV: Items Added in 2022, 1819-1880

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at The New-York Historical Society
relatedmaterial.p: Manuscript Department; call phrase: BV O'Reilly. Correspondence, scrapbooks and bound volumes of assorted historical documents, memoranda and abstracts compiled by Henry O'Reilly; the material dates from 1784 to 1862. The bulk of the correspondence and scrapbooks span the 1840s, while the historical compilations cover the period 1784 through 1820. O'Reilly's scrapbooks address such topics as the development and building of the telegraph, railroad reform, inland navigation, American journalism, agriculture in New York State, and the Civil War. O'Reilly's Western Momentos documents the downfall of the Iroquois, Robert Morris' treaty with the Senecas, and pioneer settlements in New York State. Additional printed materials related to O'Reilly are held in the collections of the New-York Historical Society Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series I contains correspondence relating to various business matters from 1837 through 1872.

scopecontent.p: Arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Subseries I.C: Letters Sent to The New-York Historical Society, 1858-1872
Letters Sent to The New-York Historical Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the O'Reilly Papers falls within this series, the Telegraph Enterprise, which documents the establishment of the electric telegraph system in the United States. In addition to documenting the organization, construction, daily management and progress of various telegraph lines, this series contains material pertaining to the controversies, disputes and litigation in which O'Reilly became involved.

did.abstract: Letters received arranged alphabetically by correspondent; letters sent arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Series III: Demoine Navigation and Railroad Company, 1849-1858
did.abstract: This series documents O'Reilly's activities as secretary of this company, which was organized in 1854 to improve the Demoine Valley.
Letters received arranged alphabetically by correspondent; letters sent arranged chronologically.
Arranged chronologically.
Arranged chronologically.
Arranged chronologically.
Arranged chronologically.
Arranged chronologically.
Series IV briefly documents O'Reilly's interest in rebuilding and enlarging the Erie Canal.

This series contains documentation on the Clinton League, which was formed in 1859 to protect the New York State canal system from the opposing policies of the state railroad system. This material reflects O'Reilly's activities as chairman of the League.
Letters received arranged alphabetically by correspondent; letters sent arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Series VI: New York State Agricultural Society, 1841-1856
did.abstract: Series VI is comprised of documents pertaining to various activities of the New York State Agricultural Society, of which O'Reilly was recording secretary. It includes material on the New York State Agricultural Fair of 1844.
Series VII documents O'Reilly's activities in New York State politics and his interest in promoting reform in the state and federal governments.
This series contains documents pertaining to O'Reilly's daily activities and duties as Post Master of Rochester. It includes material concerning mail fraud, robberies and abuses in the post office.
Series IX contains material pertaining to O'Reilly's interest in the Rochester public school system and his activities as trustee of School District No. 16 of Rochester.

did.unittitle: Series X: Rochester Athenaeum and Young Men's Association, 1838-1840
did.abstract: This series documents activities of the Rochester Athenaeum and Young Men's Association during O'Reilly's tenure as its president.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of documents pertaining to O'Reilly's interest in purchasing land in Western Virginia.

did.unittitle: Subseries XI.B: Legal documents and notes, 1838-1847
Series XII: Albany Irish Repeal Association, 1843
Series XIV: Deputy Collector and Inspector of District of Genesee, 1832-1842
Deputy Collector and Inspector of District of Genesee

Series XVI: New York Typographical Society, 1849
Series XVII: Rochester Daily Advertiser, Undated
Series XVIII: Sketches of Rochester, Undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents concerning O'Reilly's family. It includes two scrapbooks compiled by Henry O'Reilly during the Civil War about his son, Henry Brooks O'Reilly, who was killed in the battle of Williamsburg in 1862.

did.unittitle: Subseries XXII.B: Re Henry Brooks O'Reilly, 1851-1858

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains a variety of printed material, primarily news clippings, on miscellaneous subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds 51 volumes of documents, primarily print matter, compiled by Henry O'Reilly. As of 2022, these volumes had not been inventoried, but were added to the finding aid at that time. Generally, all the subject matter in this series is an extension of that found in other parts of the collection and in other N-YHS collections of O'Reilly/O'Rielly documents.

36 of the volumes relate to telegraphs, including their history, legal matters, telegraph companies, and technical aspects. Several volumes of "Western Mementoes" hold print matter concerning, mostly, western New York. One of the Western Mementoes volumes concerns Iowa, specially the Demoine Navigation Company and Des Moines River.

One volume holds documents related to the Clinton League and railroad and canal developments in New York State; three relate to agriculture; one concerns various Civil War-related matters, including the death of O'Reilly's son; one concerns the press in western New York; and one relates to political anti-Masonry.
The container list for the series lists all the volumes. Titles in "quotations" are those used by O'Reilly. Those in [brackets] were given by the processing archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged by subject matter, beginning with volumes related to the telegraph. The telegraph portion is comprised of several "series" (e.g. "journalistic series") defined by O'Reilly. Other O'Reilly series (e.g. "agricultural series") are more directly thematic.

Each album was given a unique identifier (e.g., SN-1, SN-2) by the processing archivists. These are intended only to facilitate reference and are not indicative of any overall numbering scheme found in the collection itself.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The series was added to the finding aid in April 2022 by archivist Larry Weimer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An opening title page in this volume defines the subject of the 6 volumes in this series as "history of the establishment of the electric telegraph in the United States as furnished by the public journals during the years 1845, 46, 47, 48, 50, etc." The content consists primarily of newspaper clippings and other public print matter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The miscellaneous series includes a range of print matter concerning telegraphs and telegraph companies. This first volume of 7 includes some pieces circa 1847 and the entire annual report of the Smithsonian Board of Regents for 1857 (published 1858).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds print matter concerning the Magnetic Telegraph Company (e.g., Board of Director meeting minutes, financial statements, etc.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds print matter on various telegraph companies, among them: People's Telegraph Company, New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Company, Lake Erie Telegraph Company, St. Louis & New Orleans Telegraph Company, Atlantic & Ohio Telegraph Company, Cleveland & Cincinnati Telegraph Company, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds more print matter on individual telegraph companies and on telegraph history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds a few longer print items on the science and development of the telegraph.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There is no volume marked as "Miscellaneous Series" Volume VI in this part of the collection, but the content of this volume fits within the topical framework. It includes print matter especially concerning legislation about the telegraph.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds longer print pieces: on the Pacific Railroad & Telegraph Company and a copy of the American Association for the Advancement of Science Proceedings of 1851.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds copies of the American Telegraph Magazine, from Vol 1, No. 1 in October 1852 to Vol 1, No. 6 in June 1853.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds two issues of the National Telegraph Review and Operator's Companion, Vol. 1, Nos. 1 and 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds issues of Shaffner's Telegraph Companion, Vol 1, Nos. 1-4 and Vol. 2, Nos. 2-3. (Vol 2, No. 1 is not in this volume, but is noted as being in another volume with a Smithsonian report.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 13 volumes of the "legal series" concern various lawsuits concerning telegraphs, perhaps especially with regard to patent claims. Unlike the following volumes, each of which seem focused on a particular case, this volume touches on various legal matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to Alexander Bain vs. Samuel F.B. Morse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to O'Reilly et al. vs. Samuel F.B. Morse et al.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to O'Reilly et al. vs. Samuel F.B. Morse et al.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to Francis O.J. Smith vs. Hugh Downing, et al.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to Benjamin B. French, et al. vs. Henry J. Rogers, et al.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to Benjamin B. French, et al. vs. Henry J. Rogers, et al.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to Samuel F.B. Morse & Alfred Vail vs. Francis O.J. Smith.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to Samuel F.B. Morse & Alfred Vail vs. Francis O.J. Smith.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to Samuel F.B. Morse & Alfred Vail vs. Francis O.J. Smith.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to Samuel F.B. Morse & Alfred Vail vs. Francis O.J. Smith.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to Benjamin B. French, et al. vs. Henry J. Rogers, et al.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume relates to Benjamin B. French, et al. vs. Henry J. Rogers, et al.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume was not noted as part of the "legal series" but includes print matter of contracts, leases, and other legal matters regarding telegraph companies. A notation on the inside cover indicates it was purchased for N-YHS on February 17, 1885, and so was not part of the O'Reilly donated material, but indications are that the volume was compiled by O'Reilly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Print matter related to this lawsuit. This copy includes O'Reilly's annotations and underlining. The underlying document is the same as the following (SN-43), but this one is missing the index.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This document is the same as SN-42, but includes the index. This does not appear to have been O'Reilly's copy; a notation on the first page indicates that it was given to N-YHS by Francis O.J. Smith in November 1873.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The volume holds two items: "The mural diagraph, or the art of conversing through a wall" by James Swaim (1829) and "The secret corresponding vocabulary; adapted for use to Morse's electro-magnetic telegraph" by Francis O.J. Smith (1845).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The volume holds one item: "The telegraph dictionary, and seamen's signal book" by Henry J. Rogers (1845).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume and the next are more in the nature of scrapbooks than the other volumes here. This volume holds maps, broadsides, clippings, articles of association, stock certificates, manuscript agreements and contracts, and various print matter in connection with telegraphs. O'Reilly provides contextual notes at various points. There is an 1837 letter from Samuel F.B. Morse claiming he is the inventor of the telegraph and is seeking support for that claim.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds maps, clippings, legal agreements, pamphlets and other print matter in connection with telegraphs.

did.unittitle: [Canal and railroad documents, including reports of the Clinton League]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds one book: "Sketches of Rochester" by O'Reilly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds one book: "Pioneer history of the Holland Purchase of Western New York" by O. Turner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The volume holds the book "Visit to the Falls of Niagara in 1800" by John Maude (1826), with additional notes added by Maude (1844?), and inscribed by Maude to O'Reilly (1844). O'Reilly notes that the items were bound together by him in 1878.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The volume holds two printed items inscribed by Micah Brooks to his daughter (O'Reilly's wife), Marcia: the larger item is "History of the pioneer settlement of Phelps and Gorham's Purchase, and Morris' Reserve" by O. Turner (1851); the second is an 1854 printing of "The religion of the Revolution," a 1774 discourse by David Brooks, Micah's father. There are contextual notes at the front of the volume by O'Reilly about these items and his donation to N-YHS.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds various printed matter about the Des Moines River, Demoine Navigation Company, and related re: Iowa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds "Notices [short historical accounts] of Sullivan's campaign, or the Revolutionary warfare in Western New York" and related documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds three publications of the New-York Agricultural Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume, not marked as part of Western Mementoes or another series, holds one item: the "Transactions" of the Agricultural Society for 1844 (published 1845), which follows on the volume in Western Mementoes Volume VII.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds two items: "Sketches of border adventures in the life and times of Major Moses Van Campen" by John N. Hubbard (1841) and "Life of Mary Jenison: Deh-he-wa-mis" by James E. Seaver (1856).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The volume holds an 1824 compilation by John S. Skinner of the newspaper American Farmer (Baltimore), issues 1819-1820.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The volume holds a compilation of the newspaper The Plough Boy (Albany), issues June 5, 1819 to May 27, 1820.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds:
* Printed statements of Andrew Jackson Hamilton and Lorenzo Sherwood, legislators from Texas (1862, 1864)
* Documents about raising "colored regiments" (1863-1864, 1879)
* Documents about the death of O'Reilly's son, Henry Brooks O'Reilly
* Various related clippings, notes and copies of letters.

did.unittitle: "American political-antimasonry with its 'good-enough morgan'" by O'Reilly

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume holds items related to the history of the press, printers and editors in western New York. O'Reilly provides a contextual note and index in the volume. Among the items are a manuscript memoir of publisher James D. Bemis.
